TextView.android:text: Risotto alla Milanese traces its roots back to the 16th century in Milan, Italy. Legend has it that a young glassmaker's apprentice named Valerius discovered a new technique of coloration while working on the stained glass windows of the Milanese Duomo.

1 1/2 cups Arborio rice
4 cups chicken or vegetable broth
1/2 cup dry white wine
1 small onion, finely chopped
2 tablespoons unsalted butter
1/2 cup grated Parmesan cheese, plus extra for serving
A pinch of saffron threads
Salt and pepper, to taste

Step 1: Heat the chicken or vegetable broth in a saucepan and keep it warm over low heat.

Step 2: In a separate large saucepan, melt the butter over medium heat. Add the chopped onion and sautÃ© until translucent.

Step 3: Add the Arborio rice to the saucepan with the onions and stir to coat the rice with the butter, cooking for about 2 minutes until the rice is lightly toasted.

Step 4: Pour in the white wine and cook, stirring constantly, until the wine has been absorbed by the rice.

Step 5: Add a ladleful of warm broth to the rice and stir constantly until the liquid is absorbed. Continue adding the broth, one ladleful at a time, stirring frequently and allowing each addition to be absorbed before adding more.

Step 6: After about 15 minutes of cooking, dissolve the saffron threads in a little warm broth and add it to the risotto, stirring well.

Step 7:Continue cooking the risotto until the rice is creamy and al dente, which should take about 18-20 minutes in total.

Step 8: Remove the risotto from the heat and stir in the grated Parmesan cheese. Season with salt and pepper to taste.

Step 9: Serve the risotto immediately, garnished with extra grated Parmesan cheese if desired.
